Lack enough support: The claim that drinking lemon and warm water can prevent novel coronavirus disease lacks sufficient scientific evidence to support it.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the statement from Henry Chenal, director of the Integrated Bioclinical Research Centre, who stated that consuming a high amount of vitamin C has never proved effective against coronavirus.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that consuming lemon and warm water can save lives and prevent the spread of COVID-19, without providing any substantial evidence or scientific basis.
Understate: The claim understates the importance of following the World Health Organization's recommendations, such as handwashing, coughing and sneezing etiquette, and staying at home when feeling unwell, as effective preventive measures against COVID-19.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the potential benefits of drinking lemon and warm water by attributing false claims about its effectiveness in preventing not only COVID-19 but also cancer.
Exist alternative explanation: The statement from Nicolas Boisel, a hematologist, highlights that there is no proof that drinking hot water and lemon can cure cancer, suggesting that other factors may explain the confusion or misunderstanding regarding the anti-cancer properties of lemon derivatives.
Falters at times: The claim falters in providing accurate information by attributing false claims to a non-existent university in China and misrepresenting the source of the claims as a faculty member from Zanjan University in Iran.
